column1: In 2016, Ipswich Town won a cup final against AZ Alkmaar, with Butcher playing in the team. To commemorate the victory, Butcher and a charity cycling team made a 260-mile round trip to Holland, raising money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, Gertrude, and an unnamed storm caused severe flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles. The full cost of repair is unknown, but the council will receive support under the Bellwin Scheme. However, the council must contribute £508,000 from their budget. A report outlined 240 necessary works, with 114 classified as major, to restore the impacted areas. Additional work may be needed once bridges are inspected below water level.

Thomas Cook Airlines will begin operating a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas next summer. The service will run from 4 May to 31 October and will use the airline's Airbus A330 fleet. Thomas Cook Airlines decided to introduce this regular flight due to the positive feedback received from previous one-off flights to the US. This new route is expected to provide more choices for holidaymakers and strengthen Glasgow Airport's long-haul offerings. Additionally, the airline has announced an extra flight to Tunisia for the summer of 2015.

England's national football team, along with Wales and Northern Ireland, are in pot one for the Euro 2016 draw. The Republic of Ireland's position in the draw will depend on the outcome of their play-off. Other top seeds include Spain, France, Germany, Portugal, and Belgium. Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden, and Hungary are the seeds for the play-off draw. The final draw for the tournament will be held on 12 December.

Damon Smith denies making or possessing an explosive substance with intent to endanger life but admits perpetrating a bomb hoax. The prosecution argues that Smith intended the Improvised Explosive Device (IED) to explode and endanger lives. The IED contained ball bearings to increase its destructive effect. Smith stated that he only wanted to produce smoke, but added the ball bearings to make it look like a real bomb and gain media attention. Smith has Asperger's syndrome and a fascination with weapons. The trial is ongoing.

Mansfield District Council has approved the controversial £250m Lindhurst scheme, which includes the construction of 1,700 homes, a primary school, cemetery, community center, and park. The decision was met with protests from objectors concerned about loss of countryside and congestion. However, developers believe the project will bring significant economic benefits and create up to 4,000 jobs. Some critics are calling for the secretary of state to intervene and review the decision.
Europe has the highest rate of discarding fish, with almost a quarter of catches being thrown back into the sea dead because they are not the species that the crews were targeting.

LG has acquired the WebOS operating system from HP to power its next-generation smart TV technology. The WebOS was originally created by Palm to run smartphones and tablets but lost popularity to Apple and Android. LG now gains the WebOS source code and engineers, while HP retains patents and technology to connect to web-based services. This acquisition allows LG to differentiate its products through software-based innovation.

Ipswich Town manager Mick McCarthy expressed his anger and frustration at his team's 1-1 draw against AFC Wimbledon in a pre-season friendly. McCarthy was disappointed with the late goal that allowed Wimbledon to equalize, citing similar incidents from the previous season. He emphasized the importance of not conceding goals in crucial moments and losing points from winning positions. Ipswich finished outside the Championship play-off places last season by just five points.

Tests conducted on three pairs of glasses belonging to author Jane Austen, held at the British Library, have revealed that her eyesight had significantly deteriorated. Library experts believe this may have been due to poisoning from heavy metals like arsenic, which were commonly used in medicines at the time. Austen's early death at the age of 41 has long been a subject of speculation, and this new theory adds to the discussion. The British Library is now seeking opinions from optometrists on this hypothesis.

Archbishop Justin Welby, leader of the Anglican Communion, has announced plans to fix the date for Easter Sunday. Currently, Easter is determined by the moon's cycle and can fall between 22 March and 25 April. Welby hopes that a fixed date can be agreed upon in the next five to ten years. Talks are underway with Pope Francis and leaders of the Coptic and Orthodox churches.

The latest survey by Ulster Bank on private sector activity in Northern Ireland showed a modest decline, with output and new orders decreasing. However, there was growth in the manufacturing sector, while retailers and the construction sector experienced declines. Despite the apparent weakness, companies are still hiring staff. The economist also mentioned that the new government's fiscal plans and economic policies will impact all sectors of the economy.
Opponents of a UKIP shop in Penarth have been invited to throw eggs at posters of Nigel Farage and a local candidate. No eggs have been thrown yet, according to a UKIP spokesperson.

Windsor's Theatre Royal had to halt the opening night of One Man, Two Guvnors due to flash flooding. The auditorium has been dried out and the show will continue as planned. Heavy rainfall also caused havoc in London. The flood at the theatre was unexpected, and water quickly filled the auditorium. Audience members were evacuated during the storm.

Since gaining independence from Britain in 1970, Fiji has been marked by political upheaval fueled by tension between the indigenous Fijian and ethnic Indian communities. Frank Bainimarama became prime minister in 2014, following a military coup. Jioji Konousi Konrote was elected as the non-indigenous president in 2015. Fiji has faced media restrictions since 2012, leading to self-censorship. The country has a rich history, with notable events including Dutch explorer Abel Tasman's visit in 1643 and the coups in 1987 and 1999.

The results of students in the Indian state of Bihar were suspended after a video went viral showing one student claiming that political science was about cooking. The state government had implemented measures to combat cheating, resulting in a lower pass rate. However, the recently aired interview revealed the cheating still persisted. The suspended students will now undergo a written test and interview, as well as have their handwriting checked for authenticity.

Around 30 people who had set up tents on St Peter's Square in Manchester have been forced to move after the city council obtained a warrant to close the camp. The protesters have now relocated to St Anne's Square, about half a mile away. Police and bailiffs were involved in breaking up the camp, with some protesters leaving peacefully and others resisting. The demonstrators aim to raise awareness of the housing crisis and the plight of the homeless. The council has expressed concerns about offensive graffiti, vandalism, and other inappropriate behavior. The camp has cost the council and police over £88,000 in additional expenses.

Two pieces of debris found in Mozambique are "almost certainly" from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, according to Australia's Transport Minister. The parts were found separately by members of the public and have been analysed by investigators. The discovery is consistent with drift modelling of how debris may have been carried by ocean currents and further supports the theory that the plane crashed into the Indian Ocean. The search for MH370, which disappeared in March 2014 with 239 people on board, is expected to be completed in the coming months.

The RMT union plans to hold two more days of strike action in its dispute with ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour has urged the Minister for Transport, Humza Yousaf, to intervene and end the deadlock. The RMT opposes driver-only trains and wants guards to operate the doors, claiming it is safer. However, ScotRail argues that the majority of customers already travel on trains with doors operated by the driver, and a second person is always scheduled to assist customers. Transport Scotland has called for both parties to hold meaningful discussions to end the strikes.

The Cleveland Cavaliers won their first game against the Golden State Warriors in the NBA Finals, with LeBron James leading the way with 32 points. After losing the first two games, the Cavaliers have now narrowed the series gap to 2-1. The Warriors' coach acknowledged their poor performance, while James credited his teammates for motivating him. Game four will take place in Cleveland on Friday.

Ellie Goulding's single "Burn" has topped the UK singles chart, selling 117,000 copies and beating Avicii's "Wake Me Up" by 40,000 copies. Lady Gaga's "Applause" entered the chart at number five. Goulding expressed her excitement at achieving her first UK number one single. In the album chart, Richard and Adam Johnson's "The Impossible Dream" held onto the top spot for a third consecutive week.

Highland Council in Scotland has agreed to avoid £1.3m of planned cuts by making other savings instead. These savings include changing the council's policy on sickness absence and implementing schools energy incentives. However, a proposal to cut the pay of senior councillors was defeated. The ruling group had originally proposed cuts in funding for various services, claiming that the council tax freeze had forced them to make these savings. Many local authorities in Scotland reluctantly accepted the Scottish government's funding deal, citing concerns over budget pressures.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn claims he was unfairly dismissed from his position as a gardening supervisor at HMP Littlehey in Cambridgeshire after reading Bible verses that were deemed offensive by gay prisoners. Trayhorn, an ordained Christian minister, argues that he should not have to alter his Christian beliefs to accommodate modern views on sexual ethics. His case against the secretary of state for justice is ongoing.

The independent inspector of immigration has said that the UK Home Office needs to make significant improvements in dealing with "overstayers", foreign nationals who have been refused leave to stay in the country. Failure to do so may undermine public confidence. The report suggests that the number of "overstayers" in the UK is not increasing and remains largely static. The Home Office has signed a contract with Capita to review and close the records of migrants who have been refused leave to stay, but there have been significant inaccuracies in Capita's classification of these records. This has led to the overestimation of the number of "overstayers" who have left the UK. The report also found records of 223,000 foreign nationals without permission to stay in the UK dating back to before 2008. The Immigration Minister has stated that the report's recommendations will be taken forward, and changes made by the government have had a positive impact.

The My Dentist practice in Dolgellau will be closing on 31 March due to a shortage of dentists in rural areas. The NHS practice has been unsuccessful in recruiting a permanent dentist for the last two years. The local community is concerned about the lack of access to dental services, but arrangements are being made to provide temporary dental cover until a permanent solution is found. The health board is inviting applications from dental contractors to ensure NHS services are available in the area.

A search for 26-year-old Liam Day, who went missing while climbing alone near Durlston Country Park, has been suspended after extensive efforts by police and coastguard crews. Mr. Day's partner expressed doubt about his return on social media. Enquiries are ongoing, and the police have asked for witnesses to come forward if they saw a man climbing the cliffs in the area. Climbing equipment was discovered west of Anvil Point.

Donegal manager Jim McGuinness is formulating a strategy to counter the attacking approach of defending champions Dublin in their All-Ireland semi-final. McGuinness emphasizes trust in his players to execute the game plan effectively. Despite being considered underdogs, McGuinness remains unfazed and believes in his team's ability to perform.

A report by High Fliers found that in 2015, around 1,000 graduates rejected job offers at the last minute, leaving employers to search for replacements. 20,000 students were recruited mostly at the start of their last year, giving them the opportunity to change their plans if better options came up. Top employers are competing for a limited pool of high-achieving candidates, with some graduates receiving multiple offers. Despite this, the number of graduates hired rose in 2015 and starting salaries remained stable.

A man suffered head and leg injuries after falling onto the tracks of an oncoming train at a station near Twickenham Stadium in London. The incident occurred after England's victory over Fiji in a World Cup game. The man was not critically ill and was taken to the hospital for treatment. Services between Twickenham and London Waterloo were temporarily suspended but later resumed. The cause of the incident is currently under investigation.

Malta, located south of Sicily, has a history of colonial control and was occupied by various civilizations including Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, France, and Britain. It gained independence in 1964 and is known for its strategic position as a trading post. Tourism is the main source of income. Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca is the current president, and Joseph Muscat is the prime minister. Malta became a British crown colony in 1814, gained full independence in 1964, and joined the European Union in 2004.

The film Demolition, directed by Jean-Marc Vallee and starring Jake Gyllenhaal, Naomi Watts, Chris Cooper, and Judah Lewis, premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival. The movie follows a successful investment banker who must rebuild his life after his wife's death. Vallee described the film as "the most rock 'n' roll film I've ever made" and praised Gyllenhaal's performance. The festival also featured the world premiere of Michael Moore's film Where to Invade Next. TIFF is known as the start of awards season and has historically predicted Oscar winners. Last year's People's Choice Award went to The Imitation Game.

The Belfast Telegraph reports on a boy who suffered injuries in a petrol bomb attack, with his surgery scars being scorched by flames. The Irish News highlights the controversy surrounding grants being awarded to Orange Halls in Stormont for cultural, educational, or historical purposes. The paper also covers the story of a boy using cannabis oil to treat epilepsy in the United States. Additionally, it discusses reactions to President Trump's travel ban and the upcoming decision on a prosecution case related to the Kingsmills massacre.

A recent poll conducted by Action on Hearing Loss revealed that a third of adults would ignore the "safe level" on their music players, increasing the risk of tinnitus. The survey also found that half of those surveyed listened to music for one to six hours a day. One in five respondents admitted they wouldn't take any precautionary measures to protect their hearing. Action on Hearing Loss emphasized the importance of wearing ear defenders and reducing volume levels to prevent tinnitus. DJ Paul Oakenfold supports the campaign, advocating for safe listening practices.

France emerged victorious in the Hopman Cup mixed team event as Richard Gasquet and Kristina Mladenovic defeated their American opponents. Gasquet and Mladenovic won the decisive doubles match to secure France's first title in the competition since 2014. Great Britain's team, consisting of Dan Evans and Heather Watson, were unable to advance past the group stage.

England's rugby coach Eddie Jones feels the long-standing rivalry towards England as they prepare to face Ireland at Twickenham. Jones, who is Australian, says everyone hates England but he is committed to the team. He sees Leicester centre Manu Tuilagi's future for England in the inside centre position. England is currently level with France at the top of the Six Nations table and Jones is preparing his team for an aerial bombardment from Ireland.

Paramedics in Scotland treated approximately 12,000 people who were severely intoxicated in a six-month period. This was revealed through freedom of information requests by the Scottish Conservatives. Alcohol was found to have a significant impact on the operations of the ambulance service, with more than half of all weekend call-outs attributed to alcohol-related incidents. The highest number of alcohol-related emergencies occurred in NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, followed by NHS Lothian and NHS Lanarkshire. The statistics highlight the deep-rooted issue of alcohol in Scottish society, according to the Tory health spokesman.

The 'Enabling Success' strategy has been launched in Northern Ireland to address the high rate of economic inactivity, which stands at just under 27%. The strategy aims to target three groups - those with health conditions or disabilities, lone parents, and people with caring commitments - and increase the employment rate in Northern Ireland to above the UK average by 2030. The ministers involved recognize the need for support for individuals with work-limiting conditions.

Billionaire and reality TV star Donald Trump criticized Senator John McCain, saying he was only considered a hero because he was a prisoner of war in Vietnam. Trump faced strong criticism for his comments, with rival Rick Perry calling them a "new low" in US politics. Trump later clarified his remarks but did not apologize. Many of his Republican rivals attacked him for his comments.

Canadian author W.P. Kinsella has died at the age of 81. His death was doctor-assisted, following a legal practice in Canada. Kinsella published over 30 works, including the baseball-themed fantasy novel Shoeless Joe, which was adapted into the film Field of Dreams. He suffered a head injury in a car crash and lost interest in writing fiction, but later resumed writing. His final work, Russian Dolls, is set to be released next year.

Máiría Cahill, a former member of the Irish republican movement, has won a by-election to fill a vacant seat in the Irish parliament. Previously, Cahill accused an IRA man of raping her when she was 16, but he was acquitted. Cahill has apologized for her involvement with a dissident group and pledged to use her time in parliament to support victims of abuse and help young jobseekers. She received 122 out of 188 valid votes.

ChildLine, a children's counselling charity, has launched a campaign to address the increasing number of 12 to 13-year-olds who feel addicted to pornography. The charity's offices in Cardiff and Prestatyn received calls from boys expressing concern about the impact of pornography on their thoughts and behavior. A UK-wide poll revealed that one in five children had been exposed to pornographic images that disturbed or upset them. NSPCC emphasized the importance of open dialogue on this issue to support the affected youth.

Mariner Street car park in Swansea will be replaced with a new 725-bedroom student block. This 22-story tower will include a nightclub, gym, office space, bars, restaurants, and shops. It will be the second tallest building in Swansea. Construction is set to begin later this year and finish by summer 2018. This project is seen as a positive step for High Street's regeneration and will cater to the growing need for student accommodation in the area.

Swathes of Queensland and New South Wales in Australia have been hit by floods caused by heavy rain from the remnants of Cyclone Debbie. Rivers have overflowed, prompting emergency warnings, and some towns have faced extensive damage. Power outages occurred, and even a bull shark was found in the floodwaters. However, the storm system has now moved out to sea. Insurers are not yet able to estimate the damage.

American Airlines experienced a glitch in the iPad software used by pilots and co-pilots for viewing flight plans. The company's cockpits went paperless in 2013, saving money on fuel costs. Some flights had to return to the gate to fix the issue, causing inconvenience for passengers. Other airlines have also switched to electronic flight bag-based systems, offering real-time updates and reducing flight preparation time. The cause of the glitch is still being investigated.

In a Mumbai suburb, Girish Pote was convicted for the murder of his wife in 2013. He confessed to the crime after calling his relatives, who then informed the police. Due to the gruesome nature of the crime, the judge ruled that Pote would remain in jail for the rest of his life. The couple had been fighting over money and the wife's desire to return to France.

Bradford Council has proposed plans for a one-way gyratory system in an effort to address the town's congestion issue. Deputy council leader Val Salter emphasized the need for urgent action. The plans will be showcased at the Airedale shopping centre on 11 and 13 June.

Bradford City's new signing, Kyle Thorpe, could make his debut against Millwall this weekend. The 23-year-old midfielder, who has previously played for Rotherham United, has made seven appearances this season. Despite his team sitting in seventh place in League One, they are currently outside the play-off spots by goal difference.

Spanish Prime Minister, Mariano Rajoy, was pranked by a radio presenter pretending to be Carles Puigdemont, the leader of Catalonia. During the call, the impersonator asked if they could meet and Rajoy enthusiastically agreed. However, Rajoy later realized it was a hoax and expressed disappointment. This incident highlights the political tensions surrounding the future of Catalonia and is not the first time a high-profile figure has fallen for a prank call.

The UK government has faced questions about paying detained immigrants £1 per hour for work done in immigration removal centres. Baroness Williams of Trafford defended the scheme, stating that the work is voluntary and helps to alleviate boredom for detainees. However, critics argue that detainees should be paid the minimum wage and question who benefits from the savings made by employing detainees instead of regular staff. The government has stated that the pay rate is currently being reviewed.

The winner of the Walter Scott Prize will be announced at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose later this year. Seven authors are in the running for the £25,000 prize, with judges selecting the shortlist based on their instinctive reactions to each book. The shortlisted novels offer readers joy in discovering unusual subjects and times, as well as historical research and a strong connection with the characters. The winner will be decided by judges in a meeting just before the announcement on 17 June.

Bangladesh needs just 33 runs to secure their first Test win against England, but have only two wickets left. England's Stuart Broad praised Bangladesh's skill and character, saying that the game has been exciting and both teams have played it skillfully. The match has seen a record number of reviewed decisions. The second Test will begin on Friday, and England will then go on to play a series in India.

Members of the University and College Union (UCU) at the University of Aberdeen have voted for strike action over job security at the medical school. The union claims that the four staff members affected by the potential redundancies are of Asian ethnic origin, raising concerns of discrimination. The university expressed disappointment and stated that alternative employment has been offered to the affected staff members. The strike action is scheduled to take place during the student exam period.

Jay Brenton Liptrot, the owner of a property in Prestatyn, Denbighshire, where five people died in a fire in 2012, did not enter a plea in court. Melanie Smith has already been sentenced to at least 30 years for five counts of murder for starting the fire. Mr. Liptrot will appear in court in May.

An incident occurred at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base, deemed "disgraceful" by Police Scotland. A 34-year-old man was initially expected to appear in court, but was released pending further investigations according to the Crown Office.

The "Read On. Get On." report emphasizes the long-term impact of falling behind in reading for children. Those who struggle are less likely to achieve good qualifications and continue their education. The coalition aims to ensure all 11-year-olds read well within a generation by encouraging parents to read to young children for 10 minutes a day. The report highlights the need for access to children's books in low-income households and the positive effects of early reading on future literacy.

The Belfast Giants ice hockey team has re-signed two players, Colin Shields and Mark Garside, for the upcoming season. Shields, 30, has been with the team since 2016 and expressed his excitement to continue playing. Garside, 28, will be staying with the club for an eighth year in a row. Head Coach Adam Keefe praised both players for their contributions and believes they will play a key role in the team's pursuit of trophies.

Rasmus Barlow, a 16-year-old boy, was reported missing and later found dead. The police have ruled out suspicious circumstances and are preparing a file for the coroner's office. Family liaison officers are offering support to the grieving family.

Regina Hungerford, a teacher at Merthyr Tydfil College, has been found guilty by the Education Workforce Council of making physical contact with a 17-year-old student in her classroom. Hungerford denied striking the student and claimed that she only slammed her notebook on the desk in response to his behavior. The council will decide whether to remove her from the register at a later date. Hungerford's lawyer argued that her experience with challenging students would have prevented her from striking the student.

On May 4th, big brands and individuals joined in the Star Wars Day celebration by using the hashtag #MayThe4thBeWithYou. Mark Hamill posed with his children for a Star Wars-themed family portrait, while Darth Vader also participated. Global brands used the hashtag to sell various products, and the British Museum showcased a Star Wars exhibit. Celebrities and charities also took part in raising awareness. Overall, the day was a fun and promotional event for Star Wars fans.

Several retired generals and admirals have declared their support for Republican nominee Donald Trump, stating that he has the temperament to be commander-in-chief. The letter of support was released by Trump's campaign and signed by four 4-star generals. However, Trump is also facing criticism over a political donation to a Florida official, which he did not disclose to US tax authorities. Both Trump and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton will participate in a national security forum on Wednesday. Clinton has also released a campaign ad featuring veterans critical of Trump.

The 21-year-old player joined the Tykes from QPR last summer but only made seven league appearances. He had a short loan spell at Colchester in the 2014-15 season. The left-sided player signed a one-year contract with a 12-month option at John McGreal's team. Visit our dedicated page for the latest football transfers.

Phillip Pullman, author of the His Dark Materials trilogy, is releasing a new trilogy called The Book of Dust. The first novel will be released in October, but the title is still unknown. The new series will focus on the character Lyra Belacqua, starting from her infancy and progressing to when she is 20 years old. The His Dark Materials trilogy sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages.

The American Red Cross is facing backlash for a water safety poster that has been criticized as racist. The poster, titled "Be Cool, Follow The Rules," shows black children breaking the rules while white children are depicted as behaving sensibly. The Red Cross has apologized for any offense caused and has removed the poster from their website. The Salida Pool and Recreation Department has also responded to the controversy. The issue has sparked a strong reaction online.

MK Dons chairman Peter Winkelman has confirmed that Karl Robinson will remain as the team's manager for the upcoming season. Winkelman expressed his trust in Robinson's abilities and his understanding of the club. Despite the team's relegation, Winkelman believes they are becoming a bigger club and is excited about their prospects in League One.

James Cosmo and Karen Gillan have been named as honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival (EIFF). Cosmo, known for his roles in films like Braveheart, expressed his excitement and privilege at the honor. Meanwhile, Gillan, formerly known for her role in Doctor Who, is now focused on directing and shared her joy at returning to Edinburgh, where she studied acting, to celebrate filmmaking.

Tottenham left-back Danny Rose has apologized for his recent comments about the club's wage structure and transfer policy. Rose expressed frustration at being underpaid and called for the team to sign well-known players. Manager Mauricio Pochettino has forgiven him and confirmed Rose has a future at the club. Tottenham, who finished second in the Premier League last season, have not made any signings this summer. Rose will miss their season opener due to a knee injury, but right-back Kieran Trippier's ankle injury is not as serious as initially feared.

The International Ski Federation has imposed a ban on Thai skier Vanessa Mae for allegedly manipulating race results to qualify for the Sochi Olympics. Mae finished last in the Giant Slalom, and now she and five officials are appealing the decision to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Mae has previously called the ban "nonsensical".

In a match between Eastleigh and Macclesfield Town, the visitors took an early lead with a goal from Rhys Browne. Both teams had chances throughout the game, but Macclesfield held onto their 1-0 lead. Eastleigh came close to equalizing in the 70th minute, but Ayo Obileye's header hit the post. The match ended with a victory for Macclesfield Town.

Warner Bros TV is in a salary dispute with the main cast members of The Big Bang Theory - Jim Parsons, Johnny Galecki, Kaley Cuoco, Simon Helberg, and Kunal Nayyar. If new deals cannot be reached in the next two weeks, production may be delayed. Despite this, the cast is still expected to return to work. The actors are seeking higher salaries, potentially making them the highest paid actors on US television.

A man named Alexander Worth died in a car crash on an access road in North Warnborough. Matthew Cobden, the driver of the car, appeared in court and confirmed his details. Cobden was also injured in the crash and taken to the hospital. The judge expressed sympathy to Alexander's family and the case has been referred to Winchester Crown Court for a future hearing.

Refugees in Wales are calling for action as the country welcomes the resettlement of 20,000 Syrians displaced by war. Demonstrations have been held in different cities and a human chain is planned. The need for resettlement is urgent as winter approaches for many in the refugee camps. The UK has announced plans to accept 20,000 people, prioritizing vulnerable children. The Welsh First Minister will hold a summit on the refugee crisis and local authorities are asking for financial support.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, also known as Popeye, was released from prison after serving time for his involvement in the murders orchestrated by Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar. Velasquez confessed to killing 300 people and claimed involvement in up to 3,000 killings. Despite controversy, he was released on probation after testifying against an ex-justice minister convicted of ordering a rival's murder. Velasquez's release has divided Colombians' opinions.

Warrington Wolves' Kurt Gidley became the first rugby league player to wear a camera during a match, but it was removed at half-time due to technical issues. Despite the experimental idea being intended to provide viewers with a unique perspective, coach Tony Smith emphasized that it did not affect Gidley's performance. Warrington is currently struggling in the league, but the team and broadcaster Sky Sports plan to continue the experiment after addressing the technical difficulties.

Police responded to a report of alleged sexual offenses at Auchinlee care home in Campbeltown. The Care Inspectorate is working closely with the police to monitor the situation and ensure the safety of all residents. Anyone with concerns about care services can contact the helpline provided. An 82-year-old man has been reported to the procurator fiscal in connection with the alleged offenses.

Des McDaid, a survivor of historical institutional abuse, testified at the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry in Northern Ireland. McDaid spoke about the brutality and sexual abuse he experienced at the Clontarf orphanage in Perth and his subsequent abuse by older boys and members of the Christian Brothers religious order in Australia. The inquiry is investigating child abuse in religious and state-run institutions from 1922 to 1995. McDaid also revealed his reunion with his mother, who expressed remorse for the past.

In a close match, the world number 45 lost to the reigning US Open champion in a 3-set battle. The Swiss player broke serve multiple times to claim victory. In another match, the defending champion defeated Rafael Nadal to reach the semi-finals, where he will face the third seed. Additionally, British player Aljaz Bedene lost in the quarter-final stage of the Chennai Open.

U2's lead singer, Bono, has undergone neurosurgery in Munich and is expected to have a few days of recuperation in Ireland afterward. As a result, the band's US tour date on 3 June has been postponed and their appearance at Glastonbury Festival is uncertain. Further updates on other tour dates will be provided later. The 360 Degree tour was the most profitable of 2009, earning the band approximately $109 million.

In an incident between Abergavenny and Raglan, two passengers and the pilot have been taken to the hospital, and air accident officials have been notified. The road is closed, and two fire engines are at the scene. Crews have contained a fuel leak of approximately 120 litres on board.

Angela Scott, currently the council's director of corporate governance, has been chosen to replace Valerie Watts as the new chief executive of Aberdeen City Council. Scott spoke of the financial challenges ahead but expressed confidence in the city's ability to meet them. Council leader Barney Crockett praised Scott's financial expertise and leadership skills. Scott, 42, accepted the job and expressed enthusiasm for working with elected members, colleagues, and key partners to fulfill Aberdeen's priorities. The salary for the position is reported to be £144,685.

Manchester United suffered a blow as defender Matteo Darmian dislocated his shoulder during a game against Sunderland. Manager Louis van Gaal confirmed that Darmian will be out for several weeks, adding to an already injured lineup that includes Luke Shaw, Marcos Rojo, Ashley Young, Antonio Valencia, Phil Jones, and Guillermo Varela. With only Cameron Borthwick-Jackson and Donald Love available, Van Gaal jokingly mentioned the need to line up a young player as a substitute.

Kenneth Harper's rape convictions have been overturned by the Court of Criminal Appeal in Edinburgh due to mutual corroboration concerns. Harper was given a three-year sentence for other charges including assault. Solicitor advocate John Keenan argued that the two alleged offences had significant differences and a long time gap between them. The Crown argued that there were compelling similarities, but the court found no special features to link the incidents. Harper had initially been jailed in Aberdeen.

Jim Broadbent is "thrilled" to play the role of Tommy Butler in the drama series The Great Train Robbery: A Copper's Tale. The series will follow the heist from the perspective of the robbers. Luke Evans will star in the first part of the series as Bruce Reynolds, the mastermind behind the robbery. Broadbent expressed excitement to portray Butler, a fascinating retired detective, in the upcoming drama.

A Lithuanian schoolgirl was attacked by a group of girls in Central Park in Peterborough, leaving her bruised. The girl's mother posted a video of the incident on social media, which has been viewed over 680,000 times. Police are now investigating the fight. The victim revealed that the group targeted her because they believed she was being rude to them at school. The video shows the girl being pushed to the ground and kicked repeatedly.

The Maccabees have achieved their first number one album in the UK, narrowly beating Lianne La Havas. Cilla Black's album and single have also re-entered the charts following her recent death. One Direction surprised fans with a new single, "Drag Me Down," their first since Zayn Malik's departure. Calvin Harris and Disciples' "How Deep Is Your Love" climbed to number two, while Little Mix's "Black Magic" fell to three.

After Zayn Malik left the group, rumors swirled that One Direction would break up, but the remaining members assure fans they will continue as a four-piece. Liam Payne thanked fans for their support and said the band is not finished. In the meantime, One Direction is continuing their tour in South Africa before heading to Europe. Zayn Malik has expressed his love for the fans and his former bandmates, while also hinting at a possible solo career.

Police Scotland is investigating a leak of witnesses' names and details of an alleged gun hit which were posted on social media. The police have been made aware of the communication and are conducting inquiries into the matter.

Steven Flynn broke into St Johnstone's stadium in an attempt to find money to pay off drug debts. He forced open a window with a crowbar and walked around the grounds until the police left. The break-in was only discovered when a cleaner noticed that cupboards had been rummaged through and keys and charity cash were missing. Flynn was sentenced to 16 months in jail.

Nigel Farage made a campaign visit to promote UKIP candidate Victoria Ayling in the Sleaford and North Hykeham by-election. During his speech, Farage seemed unaware of a spelling error on the UKIP poster behind him. The mistake was pointed out on social media, and the BBC contacted UKIP for a response but has not yet received one. The by-election is set to take place on Thursday.

Blair Henderson scored early on for the hosts, giving them the lead. Stirling had a chance to equalize, but Moses Olanrewaju's shot was blocked. Brian Martin was then sent off for handball, but Stirling failed to convert the resulting penalty, with Sean Dickson missing the spot kick.

Fiona Barnes, who previously faked having terminal cancer, has been sentenced to 15 months in jail for stealing £24,713 from Preston's Space Centre and perverting the course of justice. During a Proceeds of Crime hearing, she was ordered to repay only £1 as she claimed to have no money. The Space Centre expressed outrage and stated that Barnes nearly ruined them.

Adam El-Abd, a 31-year-old defender, has signed for Shrewsbury Town after being released by Bristol City. El-Abd had a long tenure at Brighton, with over 300 appearances in 11 years. He had loan spells with Bury, Swindon, and Gillingham. Shrewsbury Town manager, Micky Mellon, continues to rebuild the squad ahead of the upcoming League One campaign.

England rugby coach Eddie Jones believes that his team needs more leaders in order to win the World Cup in 2019. He stated that they currently lack consistency in leadership and that they are aiming to develop eight or nine players who can be influential. Jones also highlighted the challenges in today's society, where athletes are in more sheltered environments and not exposed to real-world experiences. England coaches are currently working on individual leadership plans to cultivate potential leaders within the team.

Somerset County Cricket Club has signed retired Australian cricketer Chris Rogers to play in the next season's County Championship. Somerset's director of cricket, Matt Maynard, praised the signing, saying Rogers will bat at number three and bring stability to the team. Maynard also highlighted Rogers' experience and hopes he can mentor younger players. Rogers retired from Test cricket earlier this year.

A Range Rover crashed into a house on Hearthcote Road in Swadlincote, Derbyshire. Although no one was injured, two residents had to leave due to concerns about structural damage. The incident is under investigation, and the police are appealing for witnesses. The front wall of the house was completely destroyed, and the road was temporarily closed. No arrests were made, and the driver only suffered minor injuries.

Work to demolish a building on Kingsway began in October 2015 but has been delayed due to the discovery of more asbestos than anticipated. The council purchased the site as part of efforts to develop a business district. Internal renovations have been finished and scaffolding is in place to support the demolition of the exterior. The project is expected to be completed by spring.

Blackburn Rovers manager, Gary Bowyer, has called for the Football League to introduce technology to help with goal line decisions. Bowyer's appeals were ignored during their 2-1 loss, and he believes technology would improve the game and ensure fairness. Goal-line technology has already been implemented in the Premier League, and Kit Symons, manager of Fulham, admitted being an advocate for its use in the Championship.

Leicester City has signed 19-year-old Polish midfielder, Bartosz Kapustka, for £7.5m on a five-year contract. Kapustka performed well for Poland in Euro 2016 and will join Leicester in Stockholm ahead of their friendly against Barcelona. He is the fifth summer signing for manager Claudio Ranieri, following the arrivals of Zieler, Hernandez, Mendy, and Musa.

The Burrell Collection in Glasgow will close for redevelopment and reopen in 2020. The building needs a new roof and the project is estimated to cost between £60m and £66m. During the closure, some works from the collection will be on display at Kelvingrove Museum. The first exhibition at Kelvingrove will feature works by the Glasgow Boys and will run from October 2016 to July 2017.

The poultry processing company, Moy Park, has met with officials from the departments of economy and finance regarding concerns over the operation of the heating subsidy scheme in Northern Ireland. The scheme allows poultry farmers to replace LPG heating systems with wood chip boilers. While the company did not address the concerns, it emphasized its experience in energy use in the poultry industry and advocated responsible heat use. The finance minister has described proposed cost control measures as inadequate.

A man's body was found in a field near Belsyde Avenue on Saturday at 11:25. Police are investigating the incident to identify the man, and a post-mortem examination will be conducted to determine the cause of death.

Ipswich Town beat AZ Alkmaar in the cup final and celebrated their victory in Amsterdam. Butcher, who played in the winning team, recently participated in a charity cycling event to Holland to commemorate the victory and raise funds for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, and Gertrude caused severe flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles. The council will receive support under the Bellwin Scheme for repairs, but they will have to contribute £508,000. A report outlined 240 necessary works, including 114 major ones. Additional work may be required after inspecting bridges below water. The full cost of repairs is yet to be calculated.

Thomas Cook Airlines will be operating a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas next summer, following successful one-off flights in recent years. The service will run from May to October using the airline's A330 fleet. The new route is a result of positive feedback and demand from customers. Glasgow Airport sees this as a valuable addition to their long-haul offerings and expects it to appeal to holidaymakers looking for more options for travel to the popular entertainment destination. In addition to Las Vegas, Thomas Cook Airlines will also be adding an extra flight to Tunisia in the upcoming summer season.

Roy Hodgson's England, along with Wales and Northern Ireland, are in pot one for the Euro 2016 finals. The Republic of Ireland's pot placement depends on the outcome of their play-off. The seedings are determined by Uefa's national team coefficient rankings. Spain, France, Germany, Portugal, and potential number one team Belgium are also top seeds. The play-off draw includes Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Sweden, and Hungary, with potential opponents for the Republic of Ireland being Denmark, Norway, or Slovenia.

Damon Smith denies making or possessing an explosive substance with intent to endanger life, but admits to perpetrating a bomb hoax. Prosecutors argue that Smith intended for the Improvised Explosive Device (IED) to explode on a train, using ball bearings as shrapnel. Smith claims he built the device solely to produce smoke but added the ball bearings to make it look more convincing. Smith, who has Asperger's syndrome, has a fascination with weapons. The trial is ongoing.

Mansfield District Council has approved the £250m Lindhurst scheme despite more than 140 objections. The project will feature 1,700 homes, a primary school, cemetery, community centre, and park. Five committee members voted in favor, five against, with the chairman's casting vote securing approval. Protesters expressed disappointment. The 169-hectare site is the largest ever submitted to the council. The Lindhurst Group, the developers, anticipate up to 4,000 jobs and positive effects on the local economy. Concerns were raised by environmental groups and residents over countryside loss and potential congestion.
Europe has the highest rate of wasteful fish discarding in the world, with nearly 25% of catches being thrown back dead. This happens because the crews end up with fish they did not intend to catch.

HP has sold its WebOS operating system to LG, who will use it to power their next-generation smart TV technology. HP acquired WebOS when it bought Palm in 2011 but was unable to recoup much of the money it paid for the company. LG will receive the source code, engineers, documentation, and websites related to WebOS, while HP retains the underlying patents and web-based services technology. This deal allows LG to differentiate its devices through software-based innovation in user experience.

Ipswich Town manager Mick McCarthy expressed frustration after his team conceded a late goal in a pre-season friendly match against U's. McCarthy was angry about the loss and stressed the importance of not allowing late goals. He pointed out past instances where his team dropped points from winning positions. Ipswich finished just outside the play-off places last season. McCarthy emphasized his displeasure at conceding a goal when they had possession of the ball.

Tests conducted on three pairs of glasses belonging to Jane Austen, held at the British Library, suggest that her deteriorating eyesight may have been due to arsenic poisoning. Austen, who suffered from rheumatism, lived in a time when heavy metals like arsenic were used in medicines. The glasses, still in good condition, showed a significant increase in lens strength, indicating her difficulty in seeing and potentially contributing to her early death at age 41. Optometrists are being invited to provide their opinions on this theory.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, has revealed that he is in discussions with other religious leaders about fixing the date of Easter. Currently, Easter falls on the first Sunday after the first full moon following the spring equinox, resulting in a variable date. Welby hopes to establish a common date for Easter within the next 5 to 10 years, but acknowledges the challenges involved in reaching an agreement amongst various Christian denominations and governments.

The latest survey by Ulster Bank shows that business conditions in Northern Ireland have declined slightly in April. It marks the fourth monthly decline in the last five months. However, the manufacturing sector saw growth in output and new orders, while retailers and the construction sector struggled. Despite the challenging conditions, companies are still hiring, with employment growth reported across all sectors except construction. The economist also mentions that the new government's policies will impact the economy.

Despite facing opposition since its opening, the high street shop in Penarth, Vale of Glamorgan, continues to be targeted by opponents. UKIP has now invited their "anarchist friends" to throw eggs at posters featuring Nigel Farage and candidate John Rees-Evans. However, no eggs have been thrown since the posters were displayed.

The opening night of "One Man, Two Guvnors" at Windsor's Theatre Royal was disrupted by flash-flooding, leading to the evacuation of the audience. Despite this, the director assures that the auditorium has been dried out and the show will continue as planned. The flood was caused by heavy rainfall, which also affected London. The incident was unprecedented for the theater, but previous minor floods had occurred over the years.

Fiji's political history has been marked by tensions between the indigenous Fijian and ethnic Indian communities. Frank Bainimarama, a former military leader, became prime minister in 2014 after a coup. Jioji Konrote, the first non-indigenous president, was elected in 2015. The government exercises control over the media through the Media Decree, leading to self-censorship. Fiji gained independence from Britain in 1970 and has experienced multiple coups and changes in leadership.

After a video of a student claiming that political science is about cooking went viral in India, the state government decided to suspend the results of the two top-scoring students and 12 others. Last year, there was a cheating scandal which led to stricter measures, resulting in a lower pass rate in this year's exams. The suspended students will have to undergo additional tests and interviews to verify their knowledge.

After losing an appeal, about 30 protesters living in tents on St Peter's Square in Manchester were forced to vacate the area as per a warrant issued by the Manchester City Council. Some protesters peacefully left the site, while others resisted. To draw attention to temporary housing and homelessness issues, the demonstrators have now established another camp in St Anne's Square, half a mile away. The council cited inappropriate behavior, increased costs, and homelessness support provided as reasons for the eviction.

Two pieces of debris found separately by members of the public in Mozambique have been confirmed to be from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. Analysis of the debris by investigators concluded that it was "almost certainly" from the aircraft. This discovery supports the belief that the search in the southern Indian Ocean is being conducted in the right area. The search will continue until the designated area has been fully explored, but without new evidence, it is expected to be completed soon.

The RMT union plans to hold two more strikes in their ongoing dispute with ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour has urged Humza Yousaf to intervene and end the deadlock. Transport Scotland claims that the minister has already engaged with both sides to find a resolution. The RMT opposes driver-only trains, while ScotRail argues that it is safe and provides assistance to customers. Transport Scotland is encouraging both parties to hold meaningful discussions to resolve the strikes.

The Cavaliers are now trailing 2-1 in the best-of-seven series after losing the first two games. Kyrie Irving scored 30 points, while Steph Curry only managed 19 for Golden State. Warriors coach Steve Kerr admitted his team wasn't prepared, and LeBron James credited his teammates for motivating him to be aggressive. Cleveland lost to Golden State in last year's Finals. Game four will also be held in Cleveland on Friday.

Ellie Goulding's single "Burn" has secured the number one spot on the UK charts, selling 117,000 copies. Lady Gaga's "Applause" debuts at number five. Miley Cyrus's "We Can't Stop" drops to number three. Goulding's previous highest charting single was her cover of Elton John's "Your Song". In the albums chart, Richard and Adam Johnson's classical album "The Impossible Dream" remains at number one for the third consecutive week.

Highland Council in Scotland will avoid £1.3m in planned cuts, but will still make other savings. Some of the savings include a revision of the council's policy on sickness absence (£500,000) and schools energy incentives (£500,000). A proposal to cut the pay of senior councillors was defeated. SNP councillors opposed cuts to services for vulnerable people. The ruling group, made up of independent councillors, proposed cuts to funding for deprived areas, street cleansing, homeless support, women's aid groups, and the Blas Music Festival. This was due in part to the council tax freeze. Other local authorities in Scotland also accepted the funding deal, reluctantly accepting the council tax freeze. Highland Council's leaders warned of job cuts and service reductions due to the inability to raise funds through tax increases.

Reverend Barry Trayhorn is involved in an ongoing case against the secretary of state for justice after he was allegedly unfairly dismissed from his position at HMP Littlehey. Trayhorn, an ordained minister, had been reading Bible verses that included a passage stating that homosexuals would not inherit the Kingdom of God. After complaints were made, he was removed from chapel services and later faced allegations of making homophobic statements. Trayhorn claims he was harassed due to his Christian faith and resigned in November 2014.

The independent inspector of immigration has called on the UK Home Office to make improvements in dealing with "overstayers" - foreign nationals who are refused permission to stay in the country. Failure to do so could affect public confidence. A report suggests that the number of "overstayers" in the UK has not been increasing. The Home Office has a contract with Capita to review and close records of refused migrants, but there have been inaccuracies in their classification of these records. The inspector identified potential overestimations in the number of "overstayers" who had departed. The Home Office will need to improve its capability to monitor and enforce immigration cases effectively.

The My Dentist practice in Dolgellau will close at the end of March due to a shortage of dentists in rural Wales. Despite efforts to recruit a dentist for the past two years, the practice was unsuccessful and can no longer provide services. The Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board intends to re-commission dental services in the area, but there may be a gap in service until a permanent solution is found. The Welsh Government expects the health board to improve access to NHS dental services.

A search has been launched for 26-year-old Liam Day, who went missing while climbing near Durlston Country Park. The search, conducted by police and coastguard crews, has been suspended for now. Liam's partner, Emily Brown, expressed doubt about his return on Facebook. Police are urging anyone with information to come forward, and climbing equipment has been found in the area. Enquiries are ongoing.

Donegal manager, Jim McGuinness, is preparing his team for a tactical battle against defending champions Dublin in the All-Ireland semi-final. McGuinness emphasizes the importance of trusting his players and giving them the necessary information to make decisions on the field. Despite being considered underdogs, McGuinness remains unfazed and focused on getting things right and having faith in his players, while disregarding external perceptions and ratings.

A report by High Fliers market research reveals that in 2015, around 1,000 graduates rejected job offers at the last minute, resulting in employers scrambling to find replacements. Approximately 20,000 students were hired, mostly in their final year. This indicates that students have the flexibility to change their plans if better opportunities arise. Top employers compete for a handful of candidates who possess strong CVs and university-acquired skills, often receiving multiple offers. The report notes that the UK's leading employers hired more graduates in 2016 than ever before. However, as the job market flourishes, graduates are becoming more selective about the companies they join. Graduate recruitment increased 3.3% in 2015, with a starting salary of £30,000, which remained steady for the second consecutive year. Higher increases in pay were observed in top law firms, investment banks, and accounting firms.

A man fell onto the train tracks at a London station, suffering head and leg injuries. The incident occurred after a World Cup game at Twickenham Stadium. The man was not critically ill and was taken to a nearby hospital for treatment. The station was evacuated during the incident, and train services were temporarily suspended. The circumstances leading to the fall are currently under investigation.

Malta, located between Europe and North Africa, has a complex history of colonial control. It gained independence from Britain in 1964 and is now known for being a leading center for trade and tourism. The population is 419,000, with Maltese and English being the major languages. Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca is the current president, while Joseph Muscat serves as the prime minister. Malta has a rich political history and joined the European Union in 2004.

The text discusses the premiere of the film "Demolition" at the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF). Directed by Jean-Marc Vallee, the tragicomedy stars Jake Gyllenhaal as a successful investment banker rebuilding his life after losing his wife. Vallee praises Gyllenhaal's performance and describes the film as his most rock 'n' roll project yet. The festival will also showcase Michael Moore's secretive film, "Where to Invade Next." TIFF is a significant event that often sets the tone for awards season.

The Belfast Telegraph focuses on a boy who suffered from a brain condition and was injured in a petrol bomb attack. His surgery scars were scorched by flames, causing blisters. The Irish News highlights grants given to Orange Halls under a controversial scheme, with one receiving £104,000 for upgrades. It also features a story about a boy with epilepsy treated with cannabis oil in the US. Reaction to President Trump's travel ban and a potential prosecution decision relating to the Kingsmills massacre are also covered.

A survey by Action on Hearing Loss reveals that many adults ignore safe volume levels on their music players, increasing their risk of tinnitus. DJ Paul Oakenfold advises wearing ear defenders and turning down the volume to protect hearing. Half of those surveyed listen to music for up to six hours a day, with one in five taking no precautions for their hearing. Tinnitus affects one in ten people in the UK daily, impacting their quality of life.

France emerged as the winners of the mixed team event at the Hopman Cup after defeating the United States in a deciding doubles match. Richard Gasquet won the men's singles match against Jack Sock, while Coco Vandeweghe won for the United States in the women's tie. Gasquet and Mladenovic then sealed the victory for France in the doubles match. This is France's second Hopman Cup title.

Australian coach Eddie Jones feels the long-standing rivalry towards England as they prepare to face Ireland at Twickenham. He acknowledges that England is a team that everyone hates, but he is committed to them. Jones believes Manu Tuilagi's best position is at inside centre and praises his skills. England is currently tied with France at the top of the Six Nations table and Jones expects Ireland to employ an aerial bombardment strategy in the upcoming match.

Around 12,000 people in Scotland were treated by paramedics for excessive alcohol consumption in the six months leading up to September. Alcohol-related incidents significantly impact the Scottish Ambulance Service, as shown by a recent internal survey. NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde had the highest number of alcohol-related call-outs, followed by NHS Lothian and NHS Lanarkshire. The stats highlight the pervasive problem of alcohol in Scottish society and the strain it places on resources. Public Health Minister Maureen Watt emphasizes the importance of responsible drinking.

A new strategy called 'Enabling Success' has been launched in Northern Ireland to address the high rate of economic inactivity which currently stands at just under 27%. The strategy aims to target three groups - those with work-limiting health conditions or disabilities, lone parents, and people with caring commitments - and increase the employment rate in Northern Ireland above the UK average by 2030. The ministers involved emphasize the importance of providing support to individuals with work-limiting conditions.

Donald Trump criticized Senator John McCain, saying he was only considered a hero because he was a prisoner of war. Trump later clarified his remarks, stating that if a person is captured, they are a hero. McCain, who was held captive for over five years during the Vietnam war, has yet to respond. Trump's comments received strong criticism, with many of his rivals for the Republican nomination attacking him.

Canadian author W.P. Kinsella died on Friday in Canada with the assistance of a doctor, as part of a legal practice introduced this year. Although no specific details of his health were provided, Kinsella was known for publishing over 30 literary works that ranged from poetry to fiction and non-fiction. His most famous novel, Shoeless Joe, was adapted into the movie Field of Dreams. Despite a head injury, Kinsella continued writing and his final work, Russian Dolls, is set to be released next year.

Máiría Cahill, a former member of the Irish republican movement, won a by-election to fill a vacant seat. She had previously accused an IRA man of raping her when she was 16. Although the accused was acquitted, a report criticized the handling of her case. Cahill no longer considers herself a republican and aims to advocate for victims of abuse in her new role as a senator.

ChildLine has launched a campaign called "Fight Against Porn Zombies" to address the significant number of 12 to 13-year-olds who believe they are addicted to porn. The charity received calls from two boys in Wales expressing concerns about the impact of pornography on them. A UK-wide poll revealed that one in five children have seen pornographic images that shocked or upset them. NSPCC national head of service for Wales urges society to openly discuss this issue.

Mariner Street car park in Swansea will be replaced with a 22-storey student block, featuring 725 bedrooms, a nightclub, gym, office space, bars, restaurants, and shops. The tower will be the second tallest building in Swansea and is expected to be completed by summer 2018. The project aims to meet the growing demand for student accommodation due to the expansion of Swansea University and Trinity Saint David universities. This development is seen as a significant step forward for the city's regeneration.

Torrential rain from the remnants of Cyclone Debbie caused widespread flooding in Queensland and New South Wales, with several rivers breaking their banks. Residents were forced to evacuate, businesses were inundated, and power was lost for tens of thousands of people. The severe weather also washed away roads and brought down trees. While the damage is still being assessed, the storm system has moved out to sea.

American Airlines experienced a glitch in the iPad software used by pilots and co-pilots for viewing flight plans. Some flights had to return to the gate to fix the issue. The airline went "paperless" in 2013, saving money on fuel and reducing the need for heavy paperwork on board. Other airlines have also switched to electronic devices for flight information. The cause of the glitch is still being investigated.

A Mumbai court has convicted Girish Pote for the gruesome 2013 murder of his wife Madhuvanti Pathak, whose body he had chopped into pieces. Pote confessed to the crime, leading to its discovery by police. Due to the heinous nature of the crime, the judge ruled that Pote would serve a life sentence for the rest of his life, which typically lasts 14 years in India. The couple had been fighting over money and Pathak's desire to return to France, where she held dual citizenship.

Bradford Council has proposed a one-way gyratory system to address the town's worsening traffic congestion. The plans, which involve East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street, will be showcased at the Airedale shopping centre on 11 and 13 June. Deputy council leader Val Salter emphasized the need for immediate action to tackle the congestion problem.

Bradford City's new signing, Ryan Thorpe, could make his debut against Millwall this Saturday. The 23-year-old midfielder, who has already made seven appearances for Rotherham United this season, will be looking to help his new team climb the League One standings. Currently sitting in seventh place, Bradford are just outside the play-off positions on goal difference. Thorpe last played in Rotherham's 5-2 loss to Ipswich on November 7th.

Spanish Prime Minister, Mariano Rajoy, was tricked into a conversation with a radio presenter posing as Catalan leader, Carles Puigdemont. During the call, Rajoy agreed to meet with Puigdemont and expressed his availability. The prank call was made amid tensions between the two leaders over the future of Catalonia. Despite being hoaxed, Rajoy took the joke well. In the past, other high-profile figures have also fallen victim to similar prank calls.

The UK government is facing criticism for paying detainees in immigration removal centres £1 per hour for voluntary work. Baroness Williams of Trafford defended the practice, stating that it helps relieve boredom and meets recreational and intellectual needs, rather than being a cost-saving scheme. Labour frontbencher Lord Rosser argued that the savings from using detainees instead of minimum-wage staff amounted to around £300,000 per month. The question of who benefits remains unanswered. The payment rate is under review, with a report expected later this year.

The winner of the Walter Scott Prize, worth £25,000, will be announced at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose. Seven novels have made the shortlist for the prize, including works by Jo Baker, Sebastian Barry, Charlotte Hobson, Hannah Kent, Francis Spufford, Graham Swift, and Rose Tremain. The judges praised the variety and quality of the longlist, stating that the shortlisted books offer readers joy in discovering unusual subjects and times, historical research, and a strong connection with the characters. The winner will be determined in a judges' meeting just before the announcement at the festival.

Bangladesh is on the verge of their first Test win against England, needing only 33 more runs with two wickets remaining. Stuart Broad praised Bangladesh's skill and said it has been an exciting game. He also mentioned the high number of reviewed decisions and the tense atmosphere. England's captain, Alastair Cook, faces a tough decision on who will open in the morning. The second Test and the upcoming series against India are still to come.

Three-quarters of members who participated in a ballot at the University of Aberdeen's medical school voted for strike action, according to UCU Scotland. A petition will also be submitted. UCU Scotland raised concerns about potential discrimination, stating that all four staff involved in the dispute are of Asian ethnic origin. The university expressed disappointment and reassured that exam disruptions would be prevented. The university believes that alternative employment offers negate the need for compulsory redundancies and asserts its commitment to equal opportunities.

Jay Brenton Liptrot, the owner of a property in Prestatyn, Wales, where five people died in a fire in 2012, appeared in court but did not enter a plea. The victims included Lee-Ann Shiers, her partner, their son, and two young nieces. Another person, Melanie Smith, has already been sentenced for starting the fire. Liptrot's case will be heard at Mold Crown Court in May.

A "disgraceful incident" occurred at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base, leading to police involvement. A 34-year-old man was initially expected to appear in court but was later released pending further investigations.

The "Read On. Get On." report emphasizes the long-term impact of children falling behind in reading. It states that this could lead to lower qualifications and limited educational opportunities. The coalition behind the report aims to ensure all 11-year-olds read well within a generation. The report highlights the need for parents to read to their children for at least 10 minutes a day. It also addresses the lack of children's books in low-income households and the importance of reading to children at an early age. The report states that 220,000 children in Scotland are living in poverty, and improving their reading skills is crucial. The Read on coalition urges collective effort to provide equal reading opportunities to all children, irrespective of their background. Currently, text messages are more commonly read by children than books, with websites and e-books gaining popularity.

The Belfast Giants ice hockey team has secured the return of two key players, Matt Martinelli and Mark Garside. Martinelli, 30, expresses his happiness at staying with the team and aims to compete for trophies in the upcoming season. Head Coach Adam Keefe praises Martinelli's positive influence on the team, while acknowledging Garside's crucial role in pursuing silverware, noting his past achievements with both the Giants and the GB national team.

A 16-year-old boy named Rasmus Barlow was reported missing by his father, leading to a police search. Unfortunately, his death has been confirmed, although it is not considered suspicious. The authorities are preparing a file for the coroner's office, and family liaison officers are providing support to Rasmus's family during this difficult time.

Regina Hungerford, a teacher at Merthyr Tydfil College, has been found to have made physical contact with a 17-year-old student in her classroom. Hungerford denies physically striking the student but admits to losing her temper and slamming a notebook on the desk. The Education Workforce Council has deemed her actions unacceptable and will consider whether to remove her from the teaching register. Hungerford's lawyer argues that her experience with challenging students makes it unlikely she would have intentionally struck the student.

Big brands, including Heathrow Airport and the British Museum, are using the #MayThe4thBeWithYou hashtag to promote their products and services on Star Wars Day. Celebrities like Mark Hamill and companies like Theo Paphitis are also joining in the fun. Charities are using the hashtag to raise awareness for their causes. It seems that for some people, every day is Star Wars Day.

A group of retired generals and admirals has declared their support for Donald Trump, stating that they believe he has the temperament to be commander-in-chief. Trump, in response, called their support an honor. Meanwhile, Trump has been facing allegations of impropriety over a political donation to a Florida official, which led to an investigation being dropped. Both Trump and Hillary Clinton will be participating in a national security forum, and Clinton released a campaign ad featuring veterans critical of Trump's comments about war heroes.

A 21-year-old player who joined Barnsley FC from QPR last summer and made only seven league appearances has signed a one-year contract with a 12-month option at Colchester. He previously had a loan spell at Colchester in the 2014-15 season. Stay informed about the latest football transfers on our dedicated page.

Phillip Pullman will release a new trilogy called The Book of Dust, with the first novel coming out in October. The series will continue the story of Lyra Belacqua, starting from when she is a baby and following her life until she is 20 years old. The His Dark Materials trilogy, which sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages, was Pullman's first book in this series.

The American Red Cross is facing criticism for a water safety poster that appears to depict black children as "not cool" while white children are portrayed as "cool." The organization has apologized for any misunderstanding and stated their commitment to diversity. The poster has been removed from their website and will no longer be printed. The issue continues to generate online backlash.

MK Dons chairman, Pete Winkelman, has confirmed that Karl Robinson will continue as manager next season. Winkelman expressed trust in Robinson and highlighted his ambition and understanding of the club. Despite the team's relegation, Winkelman acknowledged recruitment mistakes and the need for open discussions. He showed optimism about the increased pressure, seeing it as a sign of the club's growth and ambition. The MK Dons will aim to establish themselves as a big club in League One next season.

James Cosmo and Karen Gillan, both Scottish actors, have been appointed as honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival (EIFF). Cosmo, known for his roles in films like Braveheart, expressed his honor and privilege at the appointment. Gillan, known for her role in the TV series Doctor Who, shared her excitement, stating that returning to Edinburgh to celebrate filmmaking is a special honor for her.

Tottenham Hotspur left-back, Danny Rose, publicly criticized the club and their transfer strategy, claiming that he and his teammates are underpaid and that the club needs to sign well-known players. However, Rose has since apologized for his comments, and Spurs manager Mauricio Pochettino reassured that Rose still has a future at the club. Tottenham have yet to make any signings this summer and recently sold right-back Kyle Walker to Manchester City. Rose will miss the next game due to a knee injury, but Kieran Trippier's ankle injury is not as serious as initially thought.

The International Ski Federation (FIS) has punished Vanessa Mae, a violinist who represented Thailand in skiing at the Sochi Winter Olympics. She was accused of manipulating race results to secure her place at the Games. Mae finished 67th and last in the Giant Slalom event, considerably slower than the winner. Now, she has appealed the decision to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Mae had previously called her ban "nonsensical."

In a game between Eastleigh and Macclesfield Town, Rhys Browne scored the only goal in the seventh minute. Both teams had opportunities but failed to convert. Eastleigh's Ayo Obileye hit the post in the 70th minute, and Macclesfield had another disallowed goal. The match ended with Macclesfield winning 1-0.

Warner Bros TV is in negotiations with the main cast of the long-running sitcom, "The Big Bang Theory," over salaries. If new deals are not reached in the next two weeks, production may be delayed. The cast members, including Jim Parsons, Johnny Galecki, and Kaley Cuoco, currently earn $325,000 per episode and are seeking up to $1 million per show. Despite the salary disputes, the cast is still expected to return to work.

Matthew Cobden, from Walton-on-Thames, appeared in court after a crash that killed Alexander Worth in North Warnborough. Cobden confirmed his details and it was revealed he suffered serious injuries in the crash. The judge expressed sympathy to Worth's family and Cobden was granted unconditional bail. The case has been referred to Winchester Crown Court for July 26th.

Refugees and advocates gathered in Wales calling for action on the refugee crisis. The Welsh Refugee Council expressed support for resettling 20,000 Syrians in the UK. Demonstrations and a human chain were held in Swansea and Caernarfon. The severity of the crisis and the approaching winter were highlighted, emphasizing the urgent need for resettlement. The UK government has announced plans to accept refugees, prioritizing vulnerable children. The First Minister of Wales will host a summit to address the crisis.

Jhon Jairo Velasquez, known as "Popeye," was Pablo Escobar's top hitman, responsible for killing around 300 people and being involved in up to 3,000 deaths in the 1980s and 1990s. He recently left prison on probation after serving two decades and giving evidence against a former justice minister who ordered a rival's killing. Opinions in Colombia are divided on his release, with some believing he hasn't paid for his crimes while others think he deserves a second chance.

Kurt Gidley, a player for the Wolves, became the first rugby league player to wear a camera during a match, aiming to give viewers a unique perspective. However, the camera was removed at half-time due to technical issues. The Wolves coach stated that Gidley wanted to focus on playing and that the technology should not be used as an excuse for their team's poor performance. Despite the issues, Sky Sports plans to continue the experiment.

Police were called to Auchinlee care home in Campbeltown after a 76-year-old woman reported alleged sexual assault. The Care Inspectorate is working with the police to investigate the incident and ensure the safety of the residents. Concerned individuals can contact the inspectorate's helpline for assistance. An 82-year-old man has been reported to the procurator fiscal in connection with the alleged offenses.

Des McDaid, a survivor of historical institutional abuse, testified at the inquiry. He recounted his experience at the Clontarf orphanage in Perth, where he suffered both physical and sexual abuse from brothers and teachers. McDaid emphasized the feeling of helplessness he endured. He also disclosed being raped by an older boy at Termonbacca boys home before being sent to Australia. The inquiry is investigating child abuse in religious and state-run institutions in Northern Ireland.

In a thrilling match, world number 45 Kyle Edmund took the first set but eventually lost to reigning US Open champion Stan Wawrinka in two hours and 36 minutes. Wawrinka, the Swiss 31-year-old, broke serve in the second set and twice in the decider to secure the win. He will face third seed Kei Nishikori in the semi-finals.
